messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 78 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Effective poset inequalities

Paper Abstract: Abstract. We prove a number of new inequalities for the numbers of linear extensions and order polynomials of finite posets. First, we generalize the Bj√∂rner‚ÄìWachs inequality to inequalities on order polynomials and their qùëûq-analogues via direct injections and FKG inequalities, and establish several new inequalities on order polynomials. Second, we generalize actions of Coxeter groups on restricted linear extensions, leading to vanishing and uniqueness conditions for the generalized Stanley inequality. Third, we generalize the Sidorenko inequality to posets with small chain intersections and give complexity theoretic applications.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 78 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 78"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The probabilistic method",
        "Computational complexity. A modern approach",
        "Geometric inequalities for anti-blocking bodies",
        "Combinatorial Markov chains on linear extensions",
        "Computing the continuous discretely. Integer-point enumeration in polyhedra",
        "Bijective proofs of the hook formula for rooted trees",
        "When is the multiplicity of a weight equal to 111?",
        "A qùëûq-analogue of the FKG inequality and some applications",
        "qùëûq-hook length formulas for forests",
        "The bounds for the number of linear extensions via chain and antichain coverings",
        "Geometrical techniques for estimating numbers of linear extensions",
        "Unimodality, log-concavity, real-rootedness and beyond",
        "Counting linear extensions",
        "Deciding positivity of Littlewood‚ÄìRichardson coefficients",
        "A loop-free algorithm for generating the linear extensions of a poset",
        "Log-concave poset inequalities",
        "Introduction to the combinatorial atlas",
        "Multivariate correlation inequalities for PùëÉP-partitions",
        "The cross‚Äìproduct conjecture for width two posets",
        "Extensions of the Kahn‚ÄìSaks inequality for posets of width two",
        "qùëûq-analogues of Ehrhart polynomials",
        "Chromatic graph theory",
        "On log concavity for order-preserving maps of partial orders",
        "Promotion Sorting",
        "Friends and strangers walking on graphs",
        "Counting linear extensions of restricted posets",
        "A recurrence for linear extensions",
        "Systems of equations with a single solution",
        "A correlational inequality for linear extensions of a poset",
        "Counting complexity",
        "Correlation inequalities on some partially ordered sets",
        "Separable elements and splittings of Weyl groups",
        "The hull metric on Coxeter groups",
        "A Rogers‚ÄìRamanujan bijection",
        "Applications of the FKG inequality and its relatives",
        "Bijections related to statistics on words",
        "Lattice points",
        "Dual equivalence with applications, including a conjecture of Proctor",
        "How often are two permutations comparable?",
        "Order polynomial product formulas and poset dynamics",
        "Combinatorial applications of the Hodge‚ÄìRiemann relations",
        "What is in #P and what is not?",
        "Order polynomials and P√≥lya‚Äôs enumeration theorem",
        "On the conductance of order Markov chains",
        "On qùëûq-integrals over order polytopes",
        "Groups generated by involutions, Gel‚Äôfand-Tsetlin patterns, and combinatorics of Young tableaux",
        "Geometry and complexity of O‚ÄôHara‚Äôs algorithm",
        "On the qùëûq-log-concavity of Gaussian binomial coefficients",
        "Reduced matrices and qùëûq-log-concavity properties of qùëûq-Stirling numbers",
        "On positivity of Ehrhart polynomials",
        "Stanley‚Äôs non-Ehrhart-positive order polytopes",
        "Evacuation of labelled graphs",
        "Generating a random linear extension of a partial order",
        "The nature of computation",
        "Asymptotics of the number of standard Young tableaux of skew shape",
        "Why is œÄ<2‚Äãœïùúã2italic-œï\\pi<2\\phi?",
        "Combinatorial inequalities",
        "Skew shape asymptotics, a case-based introduction",
        "What is a combinatorial interpretation?",
        "On the complexity of computing Kronecker coefficients",
        "Hook inequalities",
        "Computational Complexity",
        "Bounds on mixing time of finite Markov chains",
        "Inductive proofs of qùëûq-log concavity",
        "Probabilistic algorithms for trees",
        "Combinatorial optimization. Polyhedra and efficiency",
        "Promotion des morphismes d‚Äôensembles ordonn√©s (in French)",
        "The FKG inequality and some monotonicity properties of partial orders",
        "The XYZ conjecture and the FKG inequality",
        "The extremals of the Alexandrov‚ÄìFenchel inequality for convex polytopes",
        "Inequalities for the number of linear extensions",
        "Two combinatorial applications of the Aleksandrov‚ÄìFenchel inequalities",
        "Two poset polytopes",
        "Log-concave and unimodal sequences in algebra, combinatorics, and geometry",
        "Promotion and evacuation",
        "Enumerative Combinatorics, vol. 1 (second ed.) and vol. 2",
        "Sur le volume des corps convexes sym√©triques (in French)",
        "Product decompositions of the symmetric group induced by separable permutations"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 78 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Effective poset inequalities, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
